articles.headline: Deal to Rescue American Automakers Is Moving Ahead
articles.snippet: A $15 billion government rescue of the U.S. automobile industry would be directed by Bush appointees and impose expansive oversight.
articles.abstract: A $15 billion government rescue of the U.S. automobile industry would be directed by Bush appointees and impose expansive oversight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The White House and Democratic Congressional leaders said Monday that they were close to agreeing on the terms of a $15 billion government rescue of the American automobile industry that would be directed by one or more appointees of President Bush and would impose expansive federal oversight of the auto companies.

articles.headline: Where Is Leno Going? To Prime Time, on NBC
articles.snippet: The network is expected to announce that it will give Jay Leno the 10 p.m. time period each weeknight for a show.
articles.abstract: The network is expected to announce that it will give Jay Leno the 10 p.m. time period each weeknight for a show.
articles.lead_paragraph: NBC will keep Jay Leno five nights a week, but in prime time, competing not with David Letterman, but with shows like “CSI: Miami.”

articles.headline: Tribune Company Seeks Bankruptcy Protection
articles.snippet: The chain that publishes The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune filed for bankruptcy protection just short of a year after Sam Zell took over.
articles.abstract: The chain that publishes The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune filed for bankruptcy protection just short of a year after Sam Zell took over.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Tribune Company, the newspaper and television chain that publishes The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune, filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday.

articles.headline: Workers Pay for Debacle at Tribune
articles.snippet: Sam Zell, the chief of the Tribune Company, literally mortgaged its employees’ future to pursue what one analyst called “a childhood fantasy.”
articles.abstract: Sam Zell, the chief of the Tribune Company, literally mortgaged its employees’ future to pursue what one analyst called “a childhood fantasy.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Sam Zell acknowledged from the start that his deal for the Tribune Company was flawed.

articles.headline: Next Year Is Looking Even Worse
articles.snippet: The bankruptcy filing by the Tribune Company underscored that the brunt of the injuries being suffered by the media are in local markets, especially newspapers.
articles.abstract: The bankruptcy filing by the Tribune Company underscored that the brunt of the injuries being suffered by the media are in local markets, especially newspapers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bankruptcy filing on Monday by the Tribune Company underscored that the brunt of the injuries being suffered by the media during the recession are in local markets  especially newspapers.

articles.headline: Bonus Season Afoot, Wall Street Tries for a Little Restraint
articles.snippet: Morgan Stanley is attaching a string to its annual bonuses, one that would enable the bank to yank some money back from its employees.
articles.abstract: Morgan Stanley is attaching a string to its annual bonuses, one that would enable the bank to yank some money back from its employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Wall Street pay under scrutiny as never before, Morgan Stanley is attaching a string to its annual bonuses  one that would enable the bank to yank some money back from its employees.

articles.headline: Uninsured Put a Strain on Hospitals
articles.snippet: As more people turn to emergency rooms as a last resort, doctors warn that hospitals could be overwhelmed.
articles.abstract: As more people turn to emergency rooms as a last resort, doctors warn that hospitals could be overwhelmed.
articles.lead_paragraph: As increasing numbers of the unemployed and uninsured turn to the nation’s emergency rooms as a medical last resort, doctors warn that the centers  many already overburdened  could have even more trouble handling the heart attacks, broken bones and other traumas that define their core mission.

articles.headline: Washington Takes Risks With Its Auto Bailout Plans
articles.snippet: The realignment of the auto industry described by Barack Obama sounds perilously close to a word no one in his camp wants to say: nationalization.
articles.abstract: The realignment of the auto industry described by Barack Obama sounds perilously close to a word no one in his camp wants to say: nationalization.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When President-elect Barack Obama talked on Sunday about realigning the American automobile industry he was quick to offer a caution, lest he sound more like the incoming leader of France, or perhaps Japan.

articles.headline: G.M., Under Pressure, Turns to Robert Lutz
articles.snippet: G.M.’s vice chairman, Robert A. Lutz, gave his first interviews since the Big Three’s campaign for a bailout began, and he dispensed with the polite approach his boss had used.
articles.abstract: G.M.’s vice chairman, Robert A. Lutz, gave his first interviews since the Big Three’s campaign for a bailout began, and he dispensed with the polite approach his boss had used.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  From the start of its bid for emergency federal aid from Congress, General Motors has presented a mixed message  both apologizing for past mistakes and defiantly insisting that its problems are due to the financial crisis.

articles.headline: Investors Buy U.S. Debt at Zero Yield
articles.snippet: In troubled times, making an investment that offers security but no gain is tantamount to coming out ahead.
articles.abstract: In troubled times, making an investment that offers security but no gain is tantamount to coming out ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: When was the last time you invested in something that you knew wouldn’t make money?
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Michael M. Grynbaum
